content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: List the 3 features mentioned in GitHub's Copilot product page.  Please interact with https://github.com/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to open Copilot product page. Click link “Try GitHub Copilot”.
Action: Click 1601
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to see more down the page where feature sections are; scroll window down.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to view more feature sections below; continue scrolling down.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to see further feature headings beyond Agent mode; scroll further.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to check if additional feature headings follow; scroll further down.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to review earlier content near the top for a summary list of the three key features; scroll up.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to reach the very top of the page to view the initial hero/overview section that likely summarizes the main Copilot features.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: We’re likely still mid‑page. Need to reach the very beginning (hero area) where three feature tiles are usually summarized.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: We want to reach the very top hero section; need to keep scrolling upward.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to examine the “Features” section further below the Agent mode heading; scroll a bit downward to reveal other feature headings within this section.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to view additional feature headings after “Agent mode”; continue scrolling downward.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Continue down to locate additional headings within the “Features” section after Agent mode.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down

Observation: please analyze the accessibility tree and give the Thought and Action.
[3139] RootWebArea 'GitHub Copilot · Your AI pair programmer · GitHub' focused: True url: https://github.com/features/copilot
	[4689] main ''
		[4938] sectionheader ''
		[3168] Video 'A demonstration animation of a code editor using GitHub Copilot’s agent mode, where the user requests GitHub Copilot to update their website project to allow searching for running races by name.'
		[4953] button 'A demonstration animation of a code editor using GitHub Copilot’s agent mode, where the user requests GitHub Copilot to update their website project to allow searching for running races by name. has ended. Click to replay.' pressed: true
			[8030] image ''
			[4958] StaticText 'Replay'
		[4962] emphasis ''
			[4963] StaticText 'From broken to brilliant, fast.'
		[4964] StaticText ' Need to make a sweeping change? Agent mode helps you do it quickly by analyzing code, proposing edits, running tests, and validating results across multiple files.'
		[4966] link 'Try agent mode' url: https://aka.ms/vscode-copilot-agent
		[4979] emphasis ''
			[4980] StaticText 'Plans the path, handles the work.'
		[4981] StaticText ' Agent mode reasons through the problem, coordinates next steps, and applies the changes—while keeping you in the driver’s seat.'
		[4986] emphasis ''
			[4987] StaticText 'Don’t sweat the small stuff.'
		[4988] StaticText ' From renaming variables to fixing errors, agent mode manages the tedious tasks that might otherwise break your flow.'
		[4993] heading 'Pick your brainpower'
		[4998] StaticText 'Swap between models like '
		[4999] link 'Claude 3.7 Sonnet' url: https://docs.github.com/en/copilot/using-github-copilot/using-claude-sonnet-in-github-copilot
		[5001] StaticText ', OpenAI o1, and Google Gemini 2.0 Flash to crush coding tasks fast or go deep when it counts.'
		[5003] image 'A dropdown menu lists some of GitHub Copilot’s available models like Claude 3.5 Sonnet, Claude 3.7 Sonnet, Gemini 2.0 Flash, GPT-4o, o1 (Preview) and 03-mini.' url: https://images.ctfassets.net/8aevphvgewt8/SZzlMX8i6u1JBI497nKNL/7ffb2910e43abff2e2b1b9cef7eb2800/features-models-5a96f1b6baf0.webp
		[5007] heading 'Drop an edit. Watch it spread'
		[5012] StaticText 'Next edit suggestions reveal the ripple effects of your changes across your project—helping you keep everything consistent.'
		[5014] link 'Try next edit suggestions' url: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/copilot/ai-powered-suggestions#_next-edit-suggestions
		[5022] image 'Active popover above a checkmark button indicator in front of a line of code with the options: Go To/Accept (tab key), Reject (escape key), Show Collapsed, and Settings.' url: https://images.ctfassets.net/8aevphvgewt8/11f2wKcDICAdlSFayGMnLn/92cf32e824cfaefdc9837d5a9d6653cb/features-next-edit-suggestions-73f3b1d5ca6f.webp

Thought: Another feature heading “Drop an edit. Watch it spread” is visible, and likely more follow further down; need to keep scrolling to list at least three features accurately.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down

Observation: please analyze the accessibility tree and give the Thought and Action.

		[5045] heading 'Everything you need, right where you code'
		[5060] image 'GitHub Copilot Extensions for Azure, Datastax, Docker, MongoDB and Sentry.' url: https://images.ctfassets.net/8aevphvgewt8/6CGgfIHHP25hOiNXWmbcxC/74b1f4a3b6a2316d7ece197632e999a4/copilot-extensions-f78138bbfae2.webp

ANSWER; 
1. Agent mode – GitHub Copilot works alongside you, planning changes, applying edits, running tests, and validating results.  
2. Drop an edit. Watch it spread – Next‑edit suggestions show the ripple effects of a change across your project to keep everything consistent.  
3. Your code’s guardian angel – Copilot performs automated code review, uncovering bugs and fixing mistakes before a human ever sees the code.
Format ERROR: Both 'Thought' and 'Action' should be included in your reply.

Thought: I have identified three distinct features highlighted on GitHub Copilot’s product page.  
Action: ANSWER; 
1. Agent mode – GitHub Copilot plans the solution, applies edits, runs tests, and validates results to implement sweeping changes quickly.  
2. Drop an edit. Watch it spread – Next‑edit suggestions reveal how a single change ripples across your project to keep everything consistent.  
3. Your code’s guardian angel – Automated code review analyzes your work, uncovers hidden bugs, and fixes mistakes before a human reviewer sees the code.
